metadata.title: W3Schools.com
metadata.Keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website
metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.

content.text: Linear Regressions
A Regression is a method to determine the relationship between one variable ( y ) and other variables ( x ).
content.html: A Regression is a method to determine the relationship between one variable (y) and other variables (x).

content.text: In statistics, a Linear Regression is an approach to modeling a linear relationship between y and x.
content.html: In statistics, a Linear Regression is an approach to modeling a linear relationship between y and x.

content.text: In Machine Learning, a Linear Regression is a supervised machine learning algorithm.
content.html: In Machine Learning, a Linear Regression is a supervised machine learning algorithm.

content.text: Scatter Plot
This is the scatter plot (from the previous chapter):
content.html: This is the scatter plot (from the previous chapter):

content.code_html:
const xArray = [50,60,70,80,90,100,110,120,130,140,150];
const yArray = [7,8,8,9,9,9,10,11,14,14,15];

// Define Data
 const data = [{
  x:xArray,
  y:yArray,
  mode: "markers"
}];

// Define Layout
 const layout = {
  xaxis: {range: [40, 160], title: "Square Meters"},
  yaxis: {range: [5, 16], title: "Price in Millions"},
  title: "House Prices vs. Size"
};

Plotly.newPlot("myPlot", data, layout);

content.text: Predicting Values
From the scattered data above, how can we predict future prices?
content.html: From the scattered data above, how can we predict future prices?

content.text: Linear Graphs
This is a linear graph predicting prices based on the lowest and the highest price:
content.html: This is a linear graph predicting prices based on the lowest and the highest price:

content.code_html:
const xArray = [50,60,70,80,90,100,110,120,130,140,150];
const yArray = [7,8,8,9,9,9,9,10,11,14,14,15];

const data = [
  {x:xArray, y:yArray, mode:"markers"},
  {x:[50,150], y:[7,15], mode:"line"}
];

const layout = {
  xaxis: {range: [40, 160], title: "Square Meters"},
  yaxis: {range: [5, 16], title: "Price in Millions"},
  title: "House Prices vs. Size"
};

Plotly.newPlot("myPlot", data, layout);

content.text: From a Previous Chapter
A linear graph can be written as y = ax + b
content.html: A linear graph can be written as y = ax + b

content.text: Where:
Linear Relationships
This Model predicts prices using a linear relationship between price and size:
content.html: This Model predicts prices using a linear relationship between price and size:

content.code_html:
const xArray = [50,60,70,80,90,100,110,120,130,140,150];
const yArray = [7,8,8,9,9,9,10,11,14,14,15];

// Calculate Slope
 let xSum = xArray.reduce(function(a, b){return a + b;}, 0);
let ySum = yArray.reduce(function(a, b){return a + b;}, 0);
let slope = ySum / xSum;

// Generate values
 const xValues = [];
const yValues = [];
for (let x = 50; x <= 150; x += 1) {
  xValues.push(x);
  yValues.push(x * slope);
}

content.text: In the example above, the slope is a calculated average and the intercept = 0.
content.html: In the example above, the slope is a calculated average and the intercept = 0.

content.text: Using a Linear Regression Function
This Model predicts prices using a linear regression function:
content.html: This Model predicts prices using a linear regression function:

content.code_html:
const xArray = [50,60,70,80,90,100,110,120,130,140,150];
const yArray = [7,8,8,9,9,9,10,11,14,14,15];

// Calculate Sums
 let xSum=0, ySum=0 , xxSum=0, xySum=0;
let count = xArray.length;
for (let i = 0, len = count; i < count; i++) {
  xSum += xArray[i];
  ySum += yArray[i];
  xxSum += xArray[i] * xArray[i];
  xySum += xArray[i] * yArray[i];
}

// Calculate slope and intercept
 let slope = (count * xySum - xSum * ySum) / (count * xxSum - xSum * xSum);
let intercept = (ySum / count) - (slope * xSum) / count;

// Generate values
 const xValues = [];
const yValues = [];
for (let x = 50; x <= 150; x += 1) {
  xValues.push(x);
  yValues.push(x * slope + intercept);
}

content.text: Polynomial Regression
If scattered data points do not fit a linear regression (a straight line through the points), the data may fit an polynomial regression.
content.html: If scattered data points do not fit a linear regression (a straight line through the points), the data may fit an polynomial regression.

content.text: A Polynomial Regression, like linear regression, uses the relationship between the variables x and y to find the best way to draw a line through the data points.
content.html: A Polynomial Regression, like linear regression, uses the relationship between the variables x and y to find the best way to draw a line through the data points.
